title: 109_hr4378
content: The "Defend the American Dream Act of 2005" includes provisions such as wage determination, good faith recruitment requirement, notice requirement, reduction of authorized admission period for H-1B nonimmigrants, removal of exemption from H-1B numerical limitation, and more. The "Defend the American Dream Act of 2005" includes amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding minimum wages for H-1B nonimmigrants. The employer must offer wages at the prevailing wage level, median average wage, or median wage for skill level two in the occupational classification area. The "Defend the American Dream Act of 2005" requires employers of H-1B nonimmigrants to offer wages at the prevailing wage level, median average wage, or median wage for skill level two in the occupational classification area. Employers must also provide working conditions that do not adversely affect similarly employed workers. The "Defend the American Dream Act of 2005" mandates that employers of H-1B nonimmigrants must offer wages at specified levels and provide suitable working conditions. The Secretary will require employers to submit IRS Form W-2 for such nonimmigrants. These amendments apply to applications filed after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. GOOD FAITH RECRUITMENT REQUIREMENT. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act to extend the time period for no displacement from 90 days to 180 days, require active recruitment, and prohibit outplacement of alien workers by employers. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act extend the no displacement period from 90 to 180 days, require active recruitment, and prohibit outplacement of alien workers by employers. The amendments apply to applications filed on or after the enactment date, with exceptions for displacements occurring more than 90 days before that date. SEC. 4. NOTICE REQUIREMENT. Section 212(n) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a prior notice requirement for employers applying for H-1B nonimmigrant visas. The requirement includes providing essential information about the application for public inspection. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a prior notice requirement for H-1B nonimmigrant visa applications. Employers must make the application available for public inspection at worksites and provide copies to affected workers at least 30 days before filing with the Secretary of Labor. The amendments apply to applications filed more than 30 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 reduces the authorized admission period for H-1B nonimmigrants from 6 years to 3 years. The amendment applies to those starting their admission on or after the enactment date. SEC. 6 removes the exemption from the H-1B numerical limitation for certain aliens. SEC. 6 removes the exemption from the H-1B numerical limitation for certain aliens. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act includes changes to educational institution requirements for visa applications. The effective date for these amendments is upon enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a provision to triple the H-1B nonimmigrant petitioner fee. SEC. 8 triples the H-1B nonimmigrant petitioner fee from $1,500 to $4,500. The amendment applies to petitions filed after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will oversee investigations of wage complaints and fraud in H-1B applications. Compliance audits may be conducted for employers with H-1B nonimmigrants, especially those with a high percentage of such employees. The Secretary will conduct annual compliance audits for employers with H-1B nonimmigrants. SEC. 10. PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION. A person harmed by an employer's violation of H-1B requirements may bring a civil action for damages. Effective for violations after enactment. SEC. 11. NONDISPLACEMENT REQUIREMENT applies to all H-1B employers. SEC. 11. The non-displacement requirement now applies to all employers of H-1B non-immigrants. Effective for applications filed after the enactment of this Act.
